title: Can you make water by combining hydrogen and oxygen? - Quora

response.answer_text: Chemists Joel Rosenthal and Daniel G. Nocera of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology provide this answer. When molecular hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) are combined and allowed to react together, energy is released and the molecules of hydrogen and oxygen can combine to form either water or hydrogen peroxide. These two processes are represented by the two chemical equations shown at right. Chemists use redox half-reactions to describe thermodynamic processes like the ones embodied by such equations. For both of the reactions shown, the hydrogen molecules are oxidized and the oxygen atoms are reduced. Accordingly, each of the reactions below is described by a combination of two half-reactions--one corresponding to a chemical oxidation and another corresponding to a reduction. The redox half-reaction for hydrogen oxidation is relatively simple and is shown on the left side of the scheme below. In this oxidation, a molecule of hydrogen gas is ionized to two electrons and two protons. Writing a half-reaction for oxygen reduction is more complicated, since oxygen can be reduced by either one, two or four electrons, as shown by the square redox scheme to the right, below. In most chemical reactions, molecular oxygen is reduced along the red and blue pathways highlighted in this redox scheme. The complete reduction of O2 by four electrons (4e- + 4H+, blue horizontal pathway) generates two equivalents of water whereas the corresponding two-electron reduction (2e + 2H+, red diagonal pathway) yields hydrogen peroxide. Both the two- (G = -0.695 V) and four-electron (G = -1.229 V) reductions of O2 are energetically downhill, but more than half a volt of energy is squandered in the former reaction. Accordingly, biological processes coupled to O2 reduction, such as cellular respiration, are highly selective for the complete 4e- + 4H+ pathway in order to maximize the energy available for ATP synthesis. The selective reduction of oxygen to water in such biological systems is crucial, not only in order to maximize the energy produced for cellular metabolism but also because hydrogen peroxide is a powerful oxidant and cytotoxin, which harms living cells. Given the energetics presented above, there is a strong thermochemical bias for the production of water over hydrogen peroxide when H2 and O2are reacted together. For instance, when hydrogen gas is burned in the presence of oxygen, a large amount of energy is released and water is produced as the major product. In cases where the reaction is more controlled, however, such as the consumption of hydrogen and oxygen in a fuel cell, the mechanism and kinetics of the O2 reduction process can complicate issues greatly. For instance, the delivery of the protons and electrons derived from the ionization of hydrogen (see redox half-reaction above) to a molecule of oxygen has to be precisely controlled via a process know as proton-coupled electron transfer in order to ensure that the complete four-electron reduction of O2 dominates. Platinum metal is capable of serving as a catalyst that brandishes exquisite selectivity for the four-electron reduction of oxygen to water, and accordingly lies at the heart of fuel cell design and function. Given that platinum is rare and extremely expensive, current research is aimed at the development of structural and functional models for oxygen activation and reduction to water via proton-coupled electron transfer. Similar strategies are also being exploited to drive the energetically uphill reverse reaction, in which hydrogen is produced from water using solar energy. The success of both these areas of work may ultimately prove crucial to the development and sustainability of a global hydrogen economy.

We certainly can create water easily from hydrogen and oxygen. However, you aren't going to get a Nobel Prize for solving the world clean water shortages. The problem is hydrogen. Oxygen is no problem. We are literally bathed in oxygen. It makes up a significant part of the air around us. Without it, we would all die. Hydrogen is also common. It is a major part of all the water, oil, fat, protein, carbohydrate, and cellulose that make all the people, plants and animals and many other things around us. However, hydrogen is not usually free. It is usually stuck onto elements to form a compound. Pulling the hydrogen out of that compound, so that you can use it to make your water, is hard work. It takes energy. Then you have to store that hydrogen. You don't need to store the oxygen. You can just grab that from the air as and when it is required. But you have to store the hydrogen till you are going to use it. Hydrogen is voluminous. You need a lot of hydrogen to make even just a little water. To help storage, you could cool the hydrogen and pressurise it but that is yet more hard work. It's much easier to make clean water from dirty water than to make water by generating hydrogen and burning that gas to make water. The short answer is that nature has already used all the available hydrogen to make water and greedily didn't leave any for you to play with.

Why can we not simply create water if it’s the simple combination of hydrogen and oxygen? A quick scan through the answers shows that you CAN produce water from reacting hydrogen and oxygen directly - just burn it. Everyone thinks of uncontrolled explosions, but it can be controlled and that is the basis of the hydrogen torch used for cutting through metals / welding. Oxyhydrogen - Wikipedia No-one I noticed has stated that this is the basis of the hydrogen / oxygen fuel cell (though perhaps alluded to n the reference to the movie “The Martian”). This fuel cell is used to produce electricity on space stations and the only by-product is pure drinking water that is used for drinking and rehydrating food. In this way, mass and space are minimised at a time when both are at a premium.  The combination of hydrogen and oxygen is the classic case of the conflict between thermodynamic and kinetic control… Thermodynamically the reaction is extremely exothermic, yet it doesn’t occur at all under standard conditions. The reason is, as others have stated, that the molecules must first be dissociated into atoms and the energy required for this intermediate step is too high for ordinary room temperature and pressure. That’s where the spark comes in to push the first few molecules over the activation energy barrier, releasing sufficient energy to cause a rapid chain reaction. Alternatively, and less explosively, it is possible to reduce the energy barrier by using a catalyst (platinum is good here) which allows the molecules to dissociate at room temperature and pressure by providing a surface onto which they can adsorb to form an intermediate between the catalyst and the atoms of hydrogen and oxygen - this requires far less energy than just pulling the molecules apart.

Well, you can. But it isn’t simple, for one basic reason: Where do you get that hydrogen from? The planet Earth is not massive enough to hang onto elemental hydrogen gas, and thus lost most of whatever it formed with very early on. Nearly all of Earth’s current remaining supply of hydrogen that has not escaped is bound in compounds to other, heavier atoms. And by far the most common source of…. wait for it…. ….water. And nearly every other available source (like hydrocarbons) originally got their hydrogens from reactions with water in the distant past. So in order to get the hydrogen you need to “simply” combine with oxygen to make water, you must first get the hydrogen from somewhere, and the only viable large scale source is from water itself, either directly or several steps removed. So to “create” more water you first must “destroy” pre-existing water. Which, from a practical point of view, isn’t very useful. (And the oxygen? Yeah, most of that came originally from water too….)

Yeah you can, every thing is possible in this world. But it is not a very safe thing to do. To combine hydrogen and oxygen to make water, you basically have to mix the gases together and light them with a match. Just mixing the gases together isn't enough - you have to do something to get the chemical reaction started. The problem is that this creates a big explosion(under very controlled circumstances), but it's really not something that you should try at home. For this reason, no one fills large balloons with hydrogen anymore, preferring the much safer non-flammable helium for blimps. There are plenty of other chemical reactions that you could do to make water. For instance, you can mix an acid like vinegar with a base like baking soda. This reaction will produce lots and lots of bubbles (carbon dioxide) as well as water. (But you shouldn't drink it - it will have sodium acetate in there too.)

To combine hydrogen and oxygen to make water, you basically have to mix the gases together and light them with a match. Just mixing the gases together isn't enough - you have to do something to get the chemical reaction started. The problem is that this creates a big explosion(under very controlled circumstances), but it's really not something that you should try at home.For this reason, no one fills large balloons with hydrogen anymore, preferring the much safer non-flammable helium for blimps.There are plenty of other chemical reactions that you could do to make water. For instance, you can mix an acid like vinegar with a base like baking soda. This reaction will produce lots and lots of bubbles (carbon dioxide) as well as water. (But you shouldn't drink it - it will have sodium acetate in there too.) Visit here to get hydrogen water generator

Yes. In fact the simple combustion reaction of O2(g)+2H2(g)→2H2O(g)O2(g)+2H2(g)→2H2O(g) will give you the desired result, once you’ve condensed out the water. However: Be forewarned. Combining 1 mole of Oxygen with 2 moles of H2, corresponds to about 70L of gas at STP. This will make 2 moles of water (or about 32ml) + release a lot of heat. So for a 300 ml glass, you’ll need ~227L of O2 gas and 454L of H2 gas (at STP)…and a you’ll probably wake up your neighbors if you do this all at once. Alternatively, you can be smart about it and make a hydrogen fuel cell and catalyze the reaction on a Pt surface. Note that catalyzing a reaction can work both ways. You can accelerate slow reactions or slow down fast reactions. In this case you want to slow down the reaction by first dissociating O2 and H2 on a Pt surface (following a Langmuir-Hinschelwood mechanism). O2(g)⇌2O(s)O2(g)⇌2O(s) H2(g)⇌2H(s)H2(g)⇌2H(s) Then, have O(s)+H(s)⇌HO(s)O(s)+H(s)⇌HO(s) and finally HO(s)+H(s)→H2O(g)→H2O(liq)HO(s)+H(s)→H2O(g)→H2O(liq) where X(s), X(g), and X(liq) denote whether the species is adsorbed on the surface (s), in the gas phase (g), or in liquid phase (liq). One can then use the excess heat (carried off by the H2O(g)H2O(g) and condensed to liquid) as an energy source for like a steam turbine. But, that’s now an engineering problem. I’ll leave it as an exercise for the reader (and my p-chem class this spring!) to work out the rate law.

Thanks for A2A. Yes, You can make water by simply adding hydrogen and oxygen. By the way, this is the simplest and straight way to make water but the first thing is that you have to supply some energy to the reaction (in form of heat) to start the reaction (activation energy). Please note that it is a redox reaction. In the process the oxygen is reduced and hydrogen is oxidised. Or you can in simple words call it as burning of hydrogen so in order to start the reaction you will have to mix hydrogen and oxygen in the ratio 2:1 (by volume) and ignite it the rest process is an exothermic process. And the water is formed. This is the reaction which will take place:  Please note that the burning of hydrogen is very different from burning of commercial fuel. Hydrogen burns rapidly producing instantaneous heat which can be dangerous for you.

Strange question, it is indeed a very simple reaction hydrogen and Oxygen combining to get water but what is the purpose of this? There is indeed 20% or so in the atmosphere but you will have to get hydrogen from somewhere and for sure you will lose energetically. Either you get hydrogen from water or from hydrocarbons or else. The only way to make it and still be ahead is using an enzymatic reaction powered by the sun to get your Hydrogen from renewables This hydrogen can then be used in a fuel cell to move a car or give your house energy. It is then indirect energy from the sun but still it would result in water. If we can make better fuel cells using Methanol, we could use methanol instead and eliminate the Hydrogen compression step. I believe this is the way to follow, develop a methanol economy rather than hydrogen. Enzymatic Hydrogen Production:  Conversion of Renewable Resources for Energy Production

Yes of course you can water is a combination of 2 parts hydrogen and one part oxegen. In fact hydrogen fuel cells do just that. When this occurs an electrical charge is created which is used in cats to power an electric Motor Arquably this is the most practical and environmentally friendly alternative to petrol and desil engines. Do not be taken in by the hype electric cars are a dog. There batteries require rare earth metals (the anctinides and lanctinides), which are the bottom 2 lines on the periodic table. They are called rare earth's because they are rare so to get sufficient quantities requires the processing of huge amounts of source material using quess what? Desil powered earth moving plant go figure. Many rare earth's are also radioactive making battery disposal problematic. Also in. New Zealand as in other countries, thier idn't enough juice in the system to charge the fleet even if only Half the fleet was electric. Like many things it's all hype car manufacturers like all companies want to make money, therfore they will cater to a popularist market. Note however that companies like Toyota are investing mega billions in hydrogen fuel cell technology at the expense of evs. Go figure

You can. Mix hydrogen and oxygen, add a spark, and presto! You get water. The reaction is vigorously exothermic and the reaction kinetics are quite high, so step back before you do it. The water will be very hot, so you’ll get water vapor, not liquid water. But you totally can do this. You can even take water apart and put it back together, if you like. Get a glass of water, add a pinch of salt, put two bits of bare copper wire in the glass, connect a battery, and you’ll see bubbles form on the wire. Those bubbles are hydrogen and oxygen. Collect them, combine them, strike a match, and you’ll get your water back.

Hydrogen and oxygen are both diatomic elements, being written as O2 and H2. As we know from the formula of water, there are two hydrogen atoms for every one oxygen atom, so already we see that just combining one mole of H2 and one mole of O2 is not going to work out. The balanced chemical reaction for the formation of water is as follows: 2H2 (g) + O2 (g) → 2H2O (g) Notice that both hydrogen and oxygen are in their gaseous state, and that you are combining two moles of H2 for every one mole of O2. This reaction also falls under the categorization of a combustion reaction, which is highly exothermic given the bond enthalpies involved. Thus, you cannot just combine molecules of hydrogen and oxygen; you have to combine the two constituent elements and then invest a ton of energy for water to be formed. Hope this helps!

Yes it sure can. I am skeptical there would actually be a benefit to transporting the elements in that manner. The weight would be the same but perhaps under pressure the change in volume would be helpful. It would have to be created as vapor though and then collected and put into a cup to drink. It would take some effort with vapor pressure, relative humidity, and the methods of collecting the water from where it is designed to condense. It's kind of like the backwards efforts of water forming on the exterior of a cold beverage. That's the same sort of water creation you'd get with a designed system for your purposes.

Yes... Absolutely you can make safe and pure molecular hydrogen water by combining it with oxygen. Hydrogen is a very inert gas that is very beneficial for your body.  One of the safest and simple ways to make water is hydrogen water maker machine. This machine generates pure and healthy water.  We are here to provide you hydrogen water bottle that uses the electric current to split the water into oxygen and hydrogen. This hydrogen water generator makes 100% pure and natural hydrogen water which gives you many benefits and saves you from many medical issues.  To make healthy water, you can buy hydrogen water bottles by visiting our official website. ALL THE BEST!!!

We can combine hydrogen and oxygen in 2:1 ratio to get water. But we also have to provide activation energy. Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy it takes to start a chemical reaction. Once activation energy is achieved, molecules are colliding with enough energy so that bonds are broken and new ones are formed. In a chemical reaction, not only must the molecules collide with enough energy, but they must collide into the right other molecule at the right orientation with their electrons at the proper places in order for a reaction to occur.

Yes, it is very easy. The chemistry is an oxidation known as combustion in which two gases combine to give another gas (H22O) at a higher temperature (because it is a highly exothermic reaction). If you want liquid water to drink, you also have to do some engineering (applied physics) to cool down the hot gas to a temperature at which it condenses. If you wish to drink it, I suggest down to 40 degrees C. Thus you would need some source of cooling. In the film “The Martian” the hero first makes hydrogen from rocket fuel and then water from the hydrogen; but he discovers that the energies involved make the processes quite dangerous.

Most definitely and here's what it looks like:  The shuttle's main engines were fuelled by liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen stored in the large, orange external fuel tank. Of course one of the primary methods of getting hydrogen is to separate it from water through electrolysis, so you don't actually get any more water than you started with.

Like any recipe you have to first obtain the ingredients. Oxygen from the atmosphere? Great 20% of the atmosphere is oxygen. Hydrogen from ? Whoops there is no natural source of hydrogen. You have to make if from something else. I guess now you see the problem. You have to get your hydrogen from hydrocarbons, no point in getting it from water after all, you use a lot of energy to separate hydrogen from hydrocarbons and usually the by product is carbon dioxide. There is plenty of salt water available so best to use the energy to desalinate sea water.

Absolutely possible. Measured amounts of each (twice as much hydrogen as oxygen) in a container that has the capability to have a spark introduced into the gas mixture will produce a measurable amount of water. However, while the reaction is possible it is not very efficient in terms of amount of energy used to produce small amount of H2O. That inefficiency means that it would be VERY expensive water to produce by this method.

We can make water that way. Simply burn hydrogen and viola! Water. Yay, clean pure sterile water. Since hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe we can make lots of water. Not so fast. Abundant does not mean available. All that hydrogen is either tied up in stars, gas giant planets or chemical compounds like water. There just isn't much free hydrogen around. Any free hydrogen that does happen to be around will quickly float to the top of the atmosphere and drift off into space. We can obtain hydrogen by splitting hydrogen compounds apart and recovering the hydrogen. It's just not a practical way to get water. It should be noted that water is produced by the combustion of many hydrogen compounds. Example methane CH4. CH4 + 2O2. > CO2 + 2H2O

Economics, mostly of the starting materials. Although oxygen is very abundant in the atmosphere, hydrogen is not. Hydrogen is found in water and organic material on Earth. Extracting hydrogen from water to make water does not make sense. Extracting hydrogen from organic compounds or mixtures such as petroleum to make water is not cost effective.

You can but it’s highly impractical. Perhaps that we could just create water in the middle of the desert for example? Plenty of oxygen there, but you’d have to find a way to bring in the hydrogen. At that point you might as well just fly in actual water from the nearest oasis. There is hydrogen in the atmosphere, but not enough to create water, and not for very long after it is created: If hydrogen is released into the atmosphere, what becomes of it? Does it react with oxygen to form water? Does it drift off into space?

Yes, and you do it by striking a spark. Hydrogen gas is highly flammable, when mixed with oxygen, it will burn very easily and quickly, leaving water vapor as a by-product. If this water vapor is cooled, it will condense into liquid water.  The thing is, hydrogen gas is not commonly found in nature. And it's lucky, because otherwise it would be bursting into flames at the slightest provocation.

Ok some basic chemistry here. The short answer is yes. Starting with molecular hydrogen H2 and oxygen O2. The formula is 2(h2) + o2 = 2(h2o) 2 moles of hydrogen gas plus one mole of oxygen gas yields 2 moles of water. However simply mixing the gasses together will not yield water. Energy is needed to start the reaction. In this case an electric spark or a flame. One started The hydrogen and oxygen will combine to make water. So what is happening here is simple combustion. Hydrogen is the fuel and oxygen is the oxidizer. The hydrogen burns and produces hydrogen oxide otherwise known as water.

Of course it is possible. But every reaction needs some condition to be fulfilled. Hydrogen is a very inert gas and hence to make a covalent bond with oxygen, it needs to share its only electron hence a lot of energy needs to be given as input. Practically it can be achieved by a fuel cell in which a spark is initiated such that hydrogen can burn and result in water vapour. But please dont try at home

You can, but why do you want to? There is plenty naturally, and there is no spare hydrogen lying around, which is just as well because it would explode in the oxygen. If you have been reading “The Martian”, that borders on the ridiculous. There is ice on Mars, but if you did land on a place without it, and you had hydrazine, the idea of making hydrogen is just silly. Burn the hydrazine. Burning anything with hydrogen will make water - it does not have to be pure hydrogen, although you will make something else. In the case of hydrazine, you would also make nitrogen

Because water is formed from oxygen and hydrogen atoms, and you forget to add a little activation energy? To make water molecules, you first need to break some hydrogen and oxygen molecules into atoms. Those atoms can then recombine into water. To start this off you need to add some energy e.g. in the form of a spark (fun: actually a small platinum wire is enough: it will split some hydrogen molecules on its surface). Once the process has started, there is enough energy to keep it going.

Yes, you can make water if you have oxygen and hydrogen. One of the most safest and simple way to create water from these gases is using a Fuel cell.  It can give water as well as steady supply of energy. Fuel cells are often used in space vehicles inorder to provide energy. The water obtained from it is often collected and used for drinking.

The internal combustion engine in your car is a device which combines hydrogen and oxygen to make water. Out of convenience, it uses complex organic molecules instead of pure hydrogen gas as fuel, and so it produces things other than water too - carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and some other trace gases. Its other byproduct is heat, which is the part we usually care about the most in a running car engine :-)

You can! It's done all the time and every day in the form of oxy-hydrogen torches used in cutting and welding. The vapor given off is water which will condense when cooled. If you ever saw the Space Shuttle launch, the huge white clouds are condensed steam coming from the shuttle engines which use hydrogen and oxygen for their power.

Q: Why can't I produce water by combining hydrogen and oxygen molecules? Fair question. Why can’t you? This is a reaction taking its constituents into a lower energy state, and is thermodynamically favored at atmospheric conditions. All it takes is H2, O2, and a spark. YouTube is full of such examples:  So, you’re either missing one of these three ingredients or you are not at atmospheric conditions are the only answers I can think of.

Oh, besides the answer I’ve upvoted, I just remembered a time I tried this and, when I added the necessary spark, nothing happened! In my case, and possibly in yours, you did not have good seals or you had poor transfering technique or a number of variations on that theme, and the hydrogen escaped. Hydrogen gas is much lighter than air, and with it’s tiny molecules (tiny, even compared to other molecules!), it’s molecules can escape much more easily than other gasses. tl;dr: maybe your hyrdogen leaked out

You can. The Hindenburg did it in 1937. It was an airship buoyed with hydrogen, which caught fire. But if you want to combine hydrogen and oxygen to simply create water, you can’t, because you don’t have a ready source of elemental hydrogen. Why can we not simply create water if it’s the simple combination of hydrogen and oxygen?

Well you have to perform a chemical reaction for that. Yes you can. But just mixing hydrogen and oxygen a definite ratio won't give you water. You need to give a spark or some chemical stimulus so that the molecules collide and form.water

What you can’t create are the elements hydrogen and oxygen. You can extract oxygen from compounds that contain oxygen. And you can extract hydrogen from hydrocarbons see: Hydrogen production - Wikipedia so you could make water from iron ore and methane. But you would need lot’s of iron ore and methane to make much water, and the process would be expensive. NASA is planning to make water and oxygen on the Moon and Mars by 2020 - ExtremeTech

Simply mixing hydrogen and oxygen molecules (as gases) won’t produce water. Energy must be supplied before this reaction will proceed and form water. This is often done by igniting the mixture (which is highly flammable). The heat energy causes the reaction to go to completion.

Yes, that’s exactly how the Space Shuttle ran. Combine 2 parts H and 1 part 0x and u will have an extremely exothermic reaction as the combine into water. That’s not artificial water, it’s extremely pure with no softeners or minerals. And finding the resources to do this is extremely hard and time consuming, not worth it unless we found these on another planet and used it as a survival means

Yes, indeed my friend you can. See water is H2O which means 2 atoms of hydrogen combine with 1 atom of oxygen to give you water. But also remember that the activation energy for this process is quite high, so we usually need a push at the start and then it's a self sustaining reaction

Yes. Mix the two gases and strike a match. Bang! You have explosively created water. H2(g)+O2(g)—>2H2O(g)H2(g)+O2(g)—>2H2O(g) Note that I put the product, water in the gas phase. Once it cools back down to room temp it will be liquid again.

Wrong question. Yes we can, and you can do it too.Of course they don’t react at room temp and without a source of ignition but you don’t need much science or energy to get it right. Put the 2 together in the right proportion ( stoichiometrically ) and ignite it with a ( small) spark. And kabooom you’ve just made water !

Yes, burning hydrogen in oxygen will produce water vapor, which can then be condensed to liquid water. Note that you want to do this in a controlled manner, with the hydrogen and oxygen kept separate until it reaches the burner. Filling a space with a mix of hydrogen and oxygen, and only then igniting it, will produce an explosion, as all of it burns in an instant.

Practically you can't make water by combining O2 amd H2 in their molecular form. Its practically impossible to produce water because reaction involves high energy and explosion occurs. Though this reaction is given in books but it is practically untrue. Below is the scientific demonstration of this reaction. Watch after 4.00 min.

It is possible to create water and is rather simple to do. By burning hydrogen gas you can create water. What happens is a redox reaction between the oxygen (O2) and the hydrogen (H2) that leads to water (H2O). The equation for the reaction is: 2 H2 (g) + O2 (g)→ 2 H2O (l)

Yes.. Absolutely we can produce water by combining hydrogen and oxygen.. But there is only one complication that they need their required temperature and of course pressure.. If these are there at the fixed rate then u would make water… ALL THE BEST ….

Sure, you could even extract electrical energy from the process using something called a fuel cell:  Or get the energy out not so gradually by mixing H2 and O2 and setting off a spark. NASA uses this process in some of its rocket engines.

Hydrogen when combined with oxygen in the ratio 2:1 by moles will produce water.  In fact, hydrogen is used as a fuel as well following this property only in which it reacts with oxygen to form water.
Yes.  Simply add a flame to a mixture of hydrogen and oxygen and they will rapidly combust producing water and heat.

This, in fact, is a source of water in manned spacecraft. Fuel cells are used to provide electricity when the spacecraft is in the shadow of the earth, relative to the sun. The byproduct is water that is added to the drinking water supply.

My guess is that you have some kind of deficiency that separates your capabilities from the majority of humanity that has no problem combining hydrogen and oxygen molecules. You and I are creating water and expelling it with every breath. Virtual everything you burn includes creating water. You seem simply unaware you are doing it.

You can and it’s EXTREMELY dangerous if you don’t know what you are doing… it’s the PERFECT BOMB. Don’t strike a match, or smoke with them together… or you might be, instantly, dead, dead, dead, dead, dead.

We can and we do. One awesome example was the Space Shuttle Main Engines. They burned hydrogen and oxygen to help propel the shuttle into orbit. The result was basically water… (very hot water… steam even. In fact you could almost say the space shuttle was a massive steam engine to orbit :-)

You should be able to Hydrogen burns in air/ oxygen to make water Hydrogen and oxygen can also be combined in a fuel cell to release electrical energy instead of heat and light Not sure why you are having problems…

This is very possible, and the foundation of hydrogen fuel cell technology. Storing electrical energy through hydrolysis (the splitting of water), storing the hydrogen and oxygen, and then later combining it in an exothermic reaction as a fuel supply.
During the space flights, the Americans used fuel cells, working with oxygen and hydrogen. They produced this way their drinking water. Therefore the answer is yes.
Yes, but an electrical spark needs to excite the molecules to desist being diatomic molecules and conjoin in a 2H to 1Ox atom combination to make the H2O molecule.

The molecular formula of water is H2O, meaning there are two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom in an H2O molecule. So the ratio of H2 and O2 is 2:1. Mixing them will not produce water unless you ignite it or give it a very high temperature.

It's because the molecules of both the atoms would require too huge energy which can't be easily created by us...... Also to produce H2O from Hydrogen and Oxygen, we need to overcome their Activation Energies which in turn will form the water.........
Easily; they combine to make a very hot flame, and are used for many rockets.

Yes the reaction is possible but for that you need very high temperature nearly about 1300K . And the reaction is highly exothermic, evolving a lot of heat . So it is economically not possible to produce water by this method
The clue is in the formula, H2O! A mixture of O2 and H2 can be combined catalytically, by explosion when ignited or by burning hydrogen in oxygen.
We can MAKE WATER by heating the atoms of Hydrogen and oxygen. It is possible in a HIGH TECH LABORATORY. You cannot do at home.

Except the natural process of photosynthesis, the generation of hydrogen from water requires electricity and hence, is not cost effective. Artificial photosynthesis is the only answer !
